title: Having a legitimate discussion here is nigh-impossible
body:
If you're not agreeing with a common opinion.

It doesn't matter how much you have to offer in the way of statistics or any other form of impartial, factual evidence. Most of the time, if it's not something along the lines of "Riven/Zed/Yasuo is OP!!!!" then the majority of the people on this Board will tell you to "use your game knowledge" or "learn to dodge the skillshot" or (and this is my favorite one) "learn some counterplay".

What kills me about this is that most of the time what they have to say in response is either completely wrong or so ridiculously cliché that it can be applied to anything anyone has to say about this game. For example, I had someone say that Syndra could survive a hit for 925 damage in response to a comment thread about a 925 AP Veigar's ultimate. Seriously?

I don't want to make this about elo, but the majority of the people who take these approaches to discussion are usually unranked or in low-silver tiers and believe that gameplay revolves around their experiences just because they make up the majority. This isn't to say that these behaviors only come from people on the lower end of the ladder. This isn't an elo problem -- it's a mindset problem. People who behave this way completely drive most of the discussion on this Board and choke out most perspectives that don't match their own, which is why you will never go a single day without seeing a complaint thread regarding Annie or Riven. 

I know this won't be received well, but someone had to say it.

It's not really a discussion board, I've come to realize. The forums are an echo chamber for people with a bone to pick.

The lack of discussion comes from two places:

1. **Low Elo players post things as they see them.**
2. **High Elo players don't explain things.**

I can't fault the low elo players for posting what they see in the game. They comment on the state of gameplay and balance as they see it. I'd hazard to guess that many who are asking for buffs/nerfs would be content if they had discussions which showed weaknesses/strengths that they could use in game.

Instead what happens is that more experienced players down vote them, and proceed to either give the generic advice, such as "just cc them", or mock their game knowledge. It doesn't even matter if the low elo player brings up math or stats, because they'll be dismissed as being low elo, or the high elo players will take the weakest of several points and harp on that until the end of time (this happened to me fairly recently, where I laid out 5 reasons to *consider* taking Runeglaive in lane despite it being nerfed and only 1 was talked about).

Flip the tables around, it can come off equally condemning. A high elo player makes a post (lets say it's requesting a buff for someone who's hard to deal with at low elo, but is very weak in high elo), and low elo players down vote them and post why that's a horrible idea. Again, low elo players can only post from what they see in the game. 

-------------------

I guess what I want to see from high elo players is more of a "I was there, that sucks, but then you get to this point and you realize it's not so bad" approach to G&B discussions. I remember when I first started playing against intermediate bots and thought they were very hard to beat. How I wished Riot would add a difficulty between Beginner and Intermediate! But I got better at the basic game mechanics and they stopped being a problem. I imagine that it's a similar story for anything that a low elo player can bring to these boards, where there are high elo players that have been there, but have experienced the solution to that problem themselves.

I could be wrong, but I'd guess that everyone who posts on the Gameplay & Balance board would like to be better at the game. Some may be trying for it harder than others, but everyone would like to improve. I think if more people share what they know, it'll help the boards community to become better and add a lot of worth-while discussion in between the circlejerks.

I've tried that a few times. Sometimes people are into it and listen. Most times any advice or logic gets downvoted to oblivion and nasty words get thrown my way. Even if the post is something like "Well no actually, you have counterplay strategies 1, 2, 3, 4, and sometimes 5 to deal with that thing you said was OP-BROKEN, and they work because of X, Y, and Z."

Like, I want a bit more than "rush zhonyas, get QSS, take exhaust" against Zed. Like, I know what to build, but what do I *do?*

Low elos can learn a lot from higher elos, but I've seen some noses turned up. But we make up quite a bit of the problem (there's more of us, so logic... yeah, we cause problems), especially when we act all high and mighty and ignore advice given to us in the first place (we're lower elo for a reason. Face it guys, higher elos are typically more skilled on average. Use that game knowledge to climb, not as an excuse). It's no wonder why there's so much friction. 

tl;dr: low elos could use advice, higher elos could give more advice, and both sides could be more willing to be civil about it.

I believe there are three quality of life changes that can be made to the boards to enhance discussions.

The first is a sorting issue. Almost everything is going to fall into the gameplay and balance section of the forums as that's the main concern for most players and it's just so incredibly broad. Gameplay and balance needs to be sorted into multiple sections like: map balance, jungle balance, lane balance, champion balance, and an extra category foranything else. Also champion balance could be sorted by champion allowing for even clearer issue finding.

Also it'd be great if at the end of this when someone makes a new board, someone could just redirect you to a board already discussing the matter.

The second change would be the search option. You need advanced search options to find what you need to find. If I'm looking for fiddlesticks new ability suggestions from other players it'd be great to be able to sort through those. Allowing players to easily find already made boards on what they want to talk about would really help reduce the clutter. There's probably more advantages to this that I'm overlooking.

And finally is another rating system. Something beyond a "thumbs up or thumbs down" approach. You give a rating to boards or comments based on how constructive they are. Low scores mean low constructive criticism and mostly just bitching. Thumbs up would mean you agree or dissagree with what the person said overall and the constructive rating would be based on whether the person is contributing to discussion or is trolling, whining, et cetera.

I pretty much just came up with 2 of these right now and I realize there are some problems but if you'd like to discuss them then please do.

I agree. I could write a lot about the topic as well, but to keep it short: this echo chamber (as I'm going to steal from Sachabot over there, because I like that quite a lot) isn't for rational conversation. It's constructed in such a way to be able to allow you to yell at the top of your lungs and drown out quieter conversations trying to happen beneath the cacophonous noise. Only the loudest sounds are widely heard, and when people want their frustrations known they'll let that cry out for as long as they can to make sure they can't simply be ignored. I really wanted the forums to be used for something more constructive than being an echo chamber for people gathered to pick at a bone together, and I wanted the boards to be more useful much the same, but it isn't. The format doesn't lend itself to that kind of function. It lends itself to the most popular, and the most popular topics are usually just parrots of a common opinion: speaking no original thoughts, but only what they heard before, and know that the people want to hear it again and again until some other words are fed through the mouth of the parrot.

I think we used to have a forum that promoted more discussion based on its format. It's been a long time since the old forums; I don't remember if they were better...

For what it's worth, for an extremely long time on the forums you see before you, the highest rated post of all time was a response form the community to Riot that they wanted the old forums and old forum style, instead of a Reddit clone. Based on how that whole thing went down (nothing changed, obviously) a tone was set in terms of general cynicism toward Riot the game company, its employees, and the players of this game.

Something you'll find here is that people generally don't consider other people important; it's even worse for your particular issue because there's no easy way of determining someone's skill level like there would be on Reddit (where high elo individuals post and make themselves known). You're getting the dregs here; mostly from the inability of Riot to differentiate the forums from the Reddit community.

So, yeah...

I don't understand why people don't believe statistic driven questions. Like for example win rate. Yes it's not a perfect determiner of strength but it's reasonable to assume something like jinx, ashe, or sivir is OP when they are the top 3 win rates AND The top 3 play rates at most elos. 

The same can be said of things like warwick or other champs. 

Statistics are frowned upon for no real reason. They don't belive it because... frankly I don't know why. There are numbers I sometimes question (Galio has the highest win rate for top... but a .4% pick rate with most players having >50 games on him) but things with a statistically significant sample size should really be considered more seriously.

That's because a single statistic doesn't tell the whole story. You can't determine a champion's power by win rate alone. It's still a useful thing to know, of course. As for why people ignore it, it's a common logical fallacy people use on the internet: "if it's not useful on its own, its useless". Its a very useful tool to discount a fact that doesn't agree with your point of view.

i'll address each of your points in order:

people suggested that he was weak and i gave numbers that suggested otherwise. i didn't just paste the links there without explaining the point i had in doing so, i explained that in the three tiers that make up the majority of the playerbase (bronze, silver and gold) that he was doing well in spite of the overall negative opinion of him post-rework.

I'll use another game as an example for my point later. My friends and I would play final fantasy dissidia and I'd often play Exdeath, an extremely defensive character that could block nearly any attack in the game and then counter you hard after a successful block. If played properly, there was almost nothing you could do against an exdeath other than try and fake the player out and make them whiff their block to leave them open. So in theory that character should win basically every matchup. But in practice he wasn't played as often by others and didn't win too many tournaments due to tight timing on his omni block move and high level mind games.
